animalOfTheDay.name: zonkey
facts: Their bray combines zebra whinny and donkey 'hee-haw'.
Zonkeys are sterile due to mismatched chromosomes.
They inherit donkey calmness with zebra hardiness against diseases.
Zonkeys are zebra-donkey hybrids; stripes typically appear only on legs.

calendar.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.

calendar.name: worm
facts: Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.
Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.
They improve soil aeration – moving 20 tons of earth per acre annually.
Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.

calendar.name: wren
facts: The tiny winter wren weighs less than a nickel but sings loudly.
They sing at 10 notes/second – 10x faster than human speech.
Wrens roost communally in winter; 60+ birds huddle in nest boxes.
Eurasian wrens build dome-shaped nests with side entrances – males build multiple for females to choose.

calendar.name: yak
facts: Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.
Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.
They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.

calendar.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.
They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.

calendar.name: zebu
facts: Zebus have humps storing fat for drought survival – not water.
They sweat insect-repellent oils and tolerate heat better than European cattle.
Zebu are sacred in India – 330 million gods are said to live in each.
Their loose skin helps dissipate heat in tropical climates.

calendar.name: zonkey
facts: Zonkeys are sterile due to mismatched chromosomes.
They inherit donkey calmness with zebra hardiness against diseases.
Their bray combines zebra whinny and donkey 'hee-haw'.
Zonkeys are zebra-donkey hybrids; stripes typically appear only on legs.

randomAnimals.name: tasmanian devil
facts: They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.

randomAnimals.name: warthog
facts: Warthogs have facial 'warts' that protect eyes during fights.
Birds like mongooses remove ticks from warthogs during grooming sessions.
They reverse into burrows – tusks facing outward to deter predators.
Warthogs kneel on calloused wrists to graze low vegetation.

randomAnimals.name: vulture
facts: They have an excellent sense of smell.
Vultures play a crucial role in ecosystems by cleaning up carcasses.
They are known for their bald heads, which help keep them clean while feeding.
Vultures are scavenging birds of prey.
